rev.comment: rv pov descriptions, uncited claim of fame
rev.diff:
Line 89: Line 89:
====Injury====
====Injury====
â
Theismann's career ended on November 18, [[1985 NFL season|1985]] when he suffered a gruesome comminuted [[compound fracture]] of his leg while being [[quarterback sack|sacked]] by [[New York Giants]] [[linebacker]]s [[Lawrence Taylor]] and [[Harry Carson]] during a ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game telecast. The injury was voted the NFL's "Most Shocking Moment in History" by viewers in an [[ESPN]] poll, and the tackle was dubbed "The Hit That No One Who Saw It Can Ever Forget" by ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name="washington post">{{cite news | title=The Hit That Changed a Career | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=2005-11-18 | author=Leonard Shapiro| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/11/17/AR2005111701635.html | accessdate=2008-06-30}}</ref>
+
Theismann's career ended on November 18, [[1985 NFL season|1985]] when he suffered a comminuted [[compound fracture]] of his leg while being [[quarterback sack|sacked]] by [[New York Giants]] [[linebacker]]s [[Lawrence Taylor]] and [[Harry Carson]] during a ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game telecast. The injury was voted the NFL's "Most Shocking Moment in History" by viewers in an [[ESPN]] poll, and the tackle was dubbed "The Hit That No One Who Saw It Can Ever Forget" by ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name="washington post">{{cite news | title=The Hit That Changed a Career | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=2005-11-18 | author=Leonard Shapiro| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/11/17/AR2005111701635.html | accessdate=2008-06-30}}</ref>
At the time, the Redskins had been attempting to run a [[Flea flicker (American football)|"flea-flicker"]] play. The Giants' defense, however, was not fooled, and they tried to [[blitz (American football)|blitz]] Theismann. Taylor pulled Theismann down and his hip swung over and landed on Theismann's lower right leg, fracturing both the [[tibia]] and the [[fibula]]. Giants linebackers [[Gary Reasons]] and [[Harry Carson]] then joined Taylor in the sack.
At the time, the Redskins had been attempting to run a [[Flea flicker (American football)|"flea-flicker"]] play. The Giants' defense, however, was not fooled, and they tried to [[blitz (American football)|blitz]] Theismann. Taylor pulled Theismann down and his hip swung over and landed on Theismann's lower right leg, fracturing both the [[tibia]] and the [[fibula]]. Giants linebackers [[Gary Reasons]] and [[Harry Carson]] then joined Taylor in the sack.
Line 97: Line 97:
As Theismann lay on the field, a horrified Taylor frantically screamed and waved for [[emergency medical technician]]s. Initially, however, many Redskins personnel thought Taylor's screaming and pointing directed at their sidelines was a taunt over the fact that he had successfully stopped their play. Taylor has said that his animated behavior was largely a claustrophobic reaction to having been trapped at the bottom of the pile that followed his tackle.<ref>[[Michael Lewis (author)|Michael Lewis]]. ''[[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game]]''. [[W. W. Norton]], 2006.</ref> The ''Monday Night Football'' announcer team (composed of [[Frank Gifford]], [[O. J. Simpson]] and [[Joe Namath]]) deduced from the start that Taylor was calling for help.
As Theismann lay on the field, a horrified Taylor frantically screamed and waved for [[emergency medical technician]]s. Initially, however, many Redskins personnel thought Taylor's screaming and pointing directed at their sidelines was a taunt over the fact that he had successfully stopped their play. Taylor has said that his animated behavior was largely a claustrophobic reaction to having been trapped at the bottom of the pile that followed his tackle.<ref>[[Michael Lewis (author)|Michael Lewis]]. ''[[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game]]''. [[W. W. Norton]], 2006.</ref> The ''Monday Night Football'' announcer team (composed of [[Frank Gifford]], [[O. J. Simpson]] and [[Joe Namath]]) deduced from the start that Taylor was calling for help.
â
While initially only the players on the field could see the extent of the damage to Theismann's leg, the reverse-angle instant replay provided a clearer view of what had actually happenedâTheismann's lower leg bones were broken midway between his knee and his ankle, such that his leg from his foot to his mid-shin was lying flat against the ground while the upper part of his shin up to his knee was at a 45-degree angle to the lower part of his leg. The image of his lower leg bending at such an unnatural angle has become one of the most infamous football injury images ever.
+
While initially only the players on the field could see the extent of the damage to Theismann's leg, the reverse-angle instant replay provided a clearer view of what had actually happenedâTheismann's lower leg bones were broken midway between his knee and his ankle, such that his leg from his foot to his mid-shin was lying flat against the ground while the upper part of his shin up to his knee was at a 45-degree angle to the lower part of his leg.
The compound fracture of the tibia led to insufficient bone growth during Theismann's recovery, leaving his right leg shorter than his left. As a result, the injury forced Theismann into retirement at the age of 36. Theismann has never blamed Lawrence Taylor for his injury. Taylor has said that he has never seen film of the play and never wants to. <!-- Moved WP:OR WP:CV extended quote and WP:CV video to Talk for discussion --~~~~ -->
The compound fracture of the tibia led to insufficient bone growth during Theismann's recovery, leaving his right leg shorter than his left. As a result, the injury forced Theismann into retirement at the age of 36. Theismann has never blamed Lawrence Taylor for his injury. Taylor has said that he has never seen film of the play and never wants to. <!-- Moved WP:OR WP:CV extended quote and WP:CV video to Talk for discussion --~~~~ -->
